subject: RE: The goals of CMM (Re: [junit] wanted Junit professionals urgently)
msgSnippet: ... Almost. Its more like a somewhat informed walk through an application. The direction you take on the walk is guided by a combination of some general goal
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Curt Sampson [mailto:yahoo_sucks@...]
> On Mon, 25 Aug 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>> Google "What is exploratory testing?"
>
> Interesting. Does this quote really describe exploratory testing?
>
> To the extent that the next test we do is influenced by
> the result
> of the last test we did, we are doing exploratory testing.
>
> (http://www.satisfice.com/articles/what_is_et.htm)
> This seems to me that it could just as well describe
> test-first programming; I often decide what my next test will
> be based on the previous tests I've just produced. ("Hmmm. We
> just saw and fixed a failure like such-and-such, does that
> mean that this other thing might be able to fail like that,
> too? Let's write a test and find out.")

Almost. Its more like a somewhat informed walk through an application.
The direction you take on the walk is guided by a combination of some
general goal for the testing session, where you are in the application
and what you've observed about the application so far.

Exploratory testing is usually performed on an application's end-user
interface, although I suppose you could do it at the unit level with a
debugger and interactive development environment.

> It sounds to me like the "scripted testing" he's talking
> about in that article is not XP-style testing, where you run
> the tests as you come up with them, but instead one where you
> create a whole series of tests before you take them to the
> code. Especially where he says:
>
> Scripting has its place. I can imagine testing situations where
> efficiency and repeatability are so important that we
> should script
> or automate them.
>
> I can't imagine a situation where efficiency and repeatability are
> *not* important enough to script the tests!
> But if you can
> somehow manipulate the system quickly enough to do
> exploratory testing, you can probably come up with a way for
> the script to manipulate the system even more quickly, and
> then just add your tests to the script, rather than throwing
> them away as soon as you've tried them out.
>
> cjs

The good part of ET is that you spend less time coming up with scripts
and automating and more time testing, so you have a greater liklihood of
going down a path you might not otherwise have tested. The bad part,
obviously, is that because there is no automation some paths may only
get hit once, possibly before a defect is ever inserted there.

I've seen demonstrations of Exploratory testing by experts in that
particular field. When they did find defects using this technique, they
were usually unable to reproduce them because they couldn't remember the
exact steps they had followed to get where they were. Some get around
this with a video recorder, with mixed success. Ultimately it is a
technique to consider whether to use, given your own particular context.
